text: Answer Question 1 (Section A) and three questions from Section B.
Section A carries 33% of the marks and Section B carries 67% of the marks for this paper.
You have 3 hours (plus any pre-agreed individual adjustment) to answer this paper.
Where appropriate (e.g. for formulae, equations, or diagrams) you may hand write or draw on the Inspera paper provided.
<strong>Candidates should not copy and paste figures or content from any other documents.</strong

sub-instructions: Answer all parts (a-o) of Question 1. Each part carries equal marks. Suggested total time: not more than 1 hour. As a guideline, we suggest average answers should be approximately 100 words long.
content: How do the chemistry and structures of glycogen, starch and cellulose relate to their functions?
Briefly describe three ways in which enzymes can be controlled in eukaryotic cells.
How are we able to estimate the mass of a purified protein using gel electrophoresis? Outline why this technique works with reference to protein structure.
Describe three similarities between cytochrome b6f complex of chloroplasts and complex III of mitochondria.
With examples, explain why and when NADH and NADPH are used in metabolism.
How do the enzymatic properties of hexokinase and glucokinase relate to their physiological roles in mammals?
Explain how bacteriophage T2 was used by Hershey and Chase in 1952 to determine whether protein or DNA was the primary repository of genetic information.
Describe two circumstances in which non-Mendelian uniparental inheritance takes place in an eukaryote.
How do the structure and organization of mRNAs in prokaryotes and eukaryotes facilitate translation?
What are four key features of the genetic code?
Briefly describe the chromatin immunoprecipitation and sequencing (ChIP-seq) technique and what it is used for?
How does spindle orientation specify symmetric versus asymmetric animal cell divisions?
How did cell fusion experiments predict the key roles later attributed to cyclin dependent kinases and checkpoints in cell cycle progression?
Outline how adrenaline can cause skeletal muscle contraction.
Briefly describe how to clone a frog. How would you know you had succeeded?

sub-instructions: Answer three questions from the following nine. All questions carry equal marks. Suggested total time for this section: 2 hours
content: Discuss the different bonds and forces responsible for holding protein primary, secondary, tertiary and quaternary structures together and their relative contributions to the stability of protein organization.
Eukaryotic plasma membrane Na+/K+-ATPases or H+-ATPases use approximately half of a cell’s ATP supply. Explain how and why?
Compare and contrast the various systems used to synthesize ATP.
How would you define a biochemical pathway? Illustrate your answer with specific examples.

Describe the phenomenon, discovered in sweet peas by Bateson, Saunders and Punnett, that they described as “partial gametic coupling”. How did Morgan attempt to explain this phenomenon when it was found in Drosophila? Describe how Morgan used his data to construct a genetic map. Explain why a genetic map might differ from the physical map?
Describe the experimental evidence that showed that DNA replication is bidirectional, semi-conservative and semi-discontinuous.
With reference to human syndromes and gene dosage, discuss the differences between autosomal and sex chromosome aneuploidy.
Critically discuss the concepts of "oncogenes" and "tumour suppressor genes" in the genetics of cancer.
Discuss how embryonic stem cells could be important for future disease therapies.
